Title: Repairing Toyota Sienna air filter vacuum connector

Lines.Text: 2008 toyota sienna airfilter with broken plastic vacuum connector thanks to a reckless oil change facility .

Steps.Text_raw: 2008 Toyota Sienna airfilter with broken plastic vacuum connector thanks to a reckless oil change facility.

Lines.Text: remove cover for the vehicle and carefully saw off the rest of the broken connector so it is flush with the cover and will be easier to drill out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove cover for the vehicle and carefully saw off the rest of the broken connector so it is flush with the cover and will be easier to drill out.

Lines.Text: drill out the old remaining connector with a 9 /32 inch drill bit . you must use a 9 /32 only so that the new metal connector with fit snug .

Steps.Text_raw: Drill out the old remaining connector with a 9/32 inch drill bit. ** you must use a 9/32 only so that the new metal connector with fit snug.**

Lines.Text: insert new metal connector with a little loctite glue using a small box wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert new metal connector with a little loctite glue using a small box wrench.

Lines.Text: replace airfilter ( new one if needed ) and re-attach vacuum hoses to housing in car . pat self on the back for saving 400.

Steps.Text_raw: Replace airfilter (new one if needed) and re-attach vacuum hoses to housing in car. Pat self on the back for saving $400.

Title: Installing a Tow Hitch on a 2013 RAV4

Lines.Text: the curt 56166 t-connector wiring kit comes everything i needed for this installation .

Steps.Text_raw: The Curt 56166 T-connector wiring kit comes everything I needed for this installation.

Lines.Text: remove the cargo area cover emptying all the junk and spare tire . the rear scuff panel and cargo tray on the drivers side are removed by popping the plastic rivets and metal bolts .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cargo area cover – emptying all the ‘junk’ and spare tire. The rear scuff panel and cargo tray on the driver’s side are removed by popping the plastic rivets and metal bolts.

Lines.Text: on both black side panels , there are two 12 mm bolts near the top and a 10 mm bolt on the rear post . there is cargo ring bolt at the bottom ; it can be removed for more access , but it's not necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: On both black side panels, there are two 12mm bolts near the top and a 10 mm bolt on the rear post.  There is cargo ring bolt at the bottom; it can be removed for more access, but it's not necessary.

Lines.Text: with the jbl speaker on the drivers side , it made accessing the wiring a bit tougher . ( note : the picture that came with the instructions shows the harness being accessed by removing the small vented panels . this is not accurate . the harness is located up higher and behind the rear trim . )

Steps.Text_raw: With the JBL speaker on the driver’s side, it made accessing the wiring a bit tougher.  (NOTE:  The picture that came with the instructions shows the harness being accessed by removing the small vented panels.  This is not accurate.   The harness is located up higher and behind the rear trim.)

Lines.Text: above the side panels are the rear trim panels that the plastic tools can be pried with one of the plastic tools . the top plastic rivets are tough and may slip out of the panels , but you can pop them out and slide them back on to the panel . once those are free , you can see the light harnesses on both sides .

Steps.Text_raw: Above the side panels are the rear trim panels that the plastic tools can be pried with one of the plastic tools. The top plastic rivets are tough and may slip out of the panels, but you can pop them out and slide them back on to the panel.  Once those are free, you can see the light harnesses on both sides.

Lines.Text: i used a piece of wood to brace the panels open , rather than removing them entirely :

Steps.Text_raw: I used a piece of wood to brace the panels open, rather than removing them entirely:

Lines.Text: once the side panel is free , you can see the lighting harness . do the same on the passenger side . ( note : the picture that came with the wiring instructions shows the harness being accessed by removing the small vented panels . this is not accurate . the harness is located up higher and behind the rear trim . )

Steps.Text_raw: Once the side panel is free, you can see the lighting harness. Do the same on the passenger side. (NOTE:  The picture that came with the wiring instructions shows the harness being accessed by removing the small vented panels.  This is not accurate.   The harness is located up higher and behind the rear trim.)

Lines.Text: the harness on the drivers side can be separated by pressing the small tab ( next step ) and reconnected to the red/yellow/brown t-connector coming from the converter .

Steps.Text_raw: The harness on the driver’s side can be separated by pressing the small tab (next step) and reconnected to the red/yellow/brown t-connector coming from the converter.

Lines.Text: the harness has snap connectors which come apart by pressing down on the small , thin 'handles' on the inserted part .

Steps.Text_raw: The harness has snap connectors which come apart by pressing down on the small, thin 'handles' on the inserted part.

Lines.Text: a black 12 g wire which will connect the converter box to the battery comes with the kit . attach wire to the black wire on the converter box with one of the straight connectors .

Steps.Text_raw: A black 12g wire which will connect the converter box to the battery comes with the kit. Attach wire to the black wire on the converter box with one of the straight connectors.

Lines.Text: the converter box can be attached to the rear post with the 2-sided tape that came with the kit . by removing one of the bolts of the speaker assembly , the grounding wire can be slid between the assembly and frame and the bolt re-inserted to provide a ground . ( if no speaker , a hole exists to insert a hex head bolt )

Steps.Text_raw: The converter box can be attached to the rear post with the 2-sided tape that came with the kit. By removing one of the bolts of the speaker assembly, the grounding wire can be slid between the assembly and frame and the bolt re-inserted to provide a ground. (If no speaker, a hole exists to insert a hex head bolt)

Lines.Text: the green wire to the passenger side harness can be run under the top panel which can be pried open slightly along the rubber seal . run the wire down inside the side panel . attach to t-connector to the wiring harness .

Steps.Text_raw: The green wire to the passenger side harness can be run under the top panel which can be pried open slightly along the rubber seal. Run the wire down inside the side panel.  Attach to T-connector to the wiring harness.

Lines.Text: looking from the underside of the rear metal bumper assembly , i found a rectangular rubber insert which can be removed . the connector to the trailer hitch and wire to the battery can exit the hatch area without any drilling of holes or removing the rubber plugs from the cargo pit . thread both wires down and through the post connecting the bumper .

Steps.Text_raw: Looking from the underside of the rear metal bumper assembly, I found a rectangular rubber insert which can be removed. The connector to the trailer hitch and wire to the battery can exit the hatch area without any drilling of holes or removing the rubber plugs from the cargo pit.  Thread both wires down and through the post connecting the bumper.

Lines.Text: i ran the black 12 gauge wire to the battery under the car . avoid running it through the springs and main moving parts that are part of the wheel and suspension system . there are two plastic covers that the wire can slip in to for support . tie downs can be attached after testing .

Steps.Text_raw: I ran the black 12 gauge wire to the battery under the car.  Avoid running it through the springs and main moving parts that are part of the wheel and suspension system.  There are two plastic covers that the wire can slip in to for support.  Tie downs can be attached after testing.

Lines.Text: note : some people run the cable inside the car and through a grommet fitting under the glove box . however , the wire supplied with the kit may not be long enough and the purchase of one that is will be required .

Steps.Text_raw: NOTE: some people run the cable inside the car and through a grommet fitting under the glove box. However, the wire supplied with the kit may not be long enough and the purchase of one that is will be required.

Lines.Text: once in the engine compartment , '''remove the negative terminal''' . attach one of the red fuse link wires to the 12 g wire with the remaining straight connector and the other part of the fuse link to the battery positive side using the round connector . insert the fuse . re-attach the negative terminal and check with trailer wire tester .

Steps.Text_raw: Once in the engine compartment, '''remove the negative terminal'''.  Attach one of the red fuse link wires to the 12g wire with the remaining straight connector and  the other part of the fuse link to the battery positive side using the round connector.  Insert the fuse.  Re-attach the negative terminal and check with trailer wire tester.

Lines.Text: use the black tie-downs to secure the 12 g wire to the vehicle frame . avoid attaching it to any of the moving parts like the suspension springs , etc . .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the black tie-downs to secure the 12g wire to the vehicle frame.  Avoid attaching it to any of the moving parts like the suspension springs, etc..

Lines.Text: the curt hitch 13149 comes with 4 bolts that fit into the pre-drilled holes on the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: The Curt hitch 13149 comes with 4 bolts that fit into the pre-drilled holes on the frame.

Lines.Text: with wiring complete , installing the hitch first required removing the muffler from the rear exhaust isolator , a rubber bracket holding the metal peg attached to the muffler . some people find this step unnecessary , but working alone , doing this made the installation easier .

Steps.Text_raw: With wiring complete, installing the hitch first required removing the muffler from the rear exhaust isolator, a rubber bracket holding the metal peg attached to the muffler.  Some people find this step unnecessary, but working alone, doing this made the installation easier.

Lines.Text: the driver's side has a hidden hitch bracket which needs to be unbolted from the frame before the hitch can be attached . one of those holes will be used and another uncovered to attach that side of the hitch .

Steps.Text_raw: The driver's side has a hidden hitch bracket which needs to be unbolted from the frame before the hitch can be attached.  One of those holes will be used and another uncovered to attach that side of the hitch.

Lines.Text: there is a metal 'y' bolted to the top of the muffler that prevents it from swaying into the gas tank . if after installing the hitch , you hear it rattling against the hitch , try removing the two hex bolts and reversing it .

Steps.Text_raw: There is a metal 'Y' bolted to the top of the muffler that prevents it from swaying into the gas tank.  If after installing the hitch, you hear it rattling against the hitch, try removing the two hex bolts and reversing it.

Lines.Text: with the muffler free , it was easier to access the passenger side frame where pre-drilled holes existed . they are covered by a thin piece of material which can be scrapped off . i applied some grease to the hitch bolts before inserting and torquing them to 86 foot pounds .

Steps.Text_raw: With the muffler free, it was easier to access the passenger side frame where pre-drilled holes existed.  They are covered by a thin piece of material which can be scrapped off.  I applied some grease to the hitch bolts before inserting and torquing them to 86 foot pounds.

Lines.Text: back to the driver's side , i used the supplied bolts , greasing them and torquing as on the passenger side .

Steps.Text_raw: Back to the driver's side, I used the supplied bolts, greasing them and torquing as on the passenger side.

Title: 2000-2006 Toyota Celica Front Sway Bar Link Replacement

Lines.Text: '''tools needed : '''
a 14 mm socket wrench
a 4 mm allen wrench
penetrating lubricant
a lug wrench
torque wrench
two new sway bar links

Steps.Text_raw: '''Tools needed:''' A 14mm socket wrench A 4mm Allen wrench Penetrating lubricant A lug wrench Torque wrench Two new sway bar links

Lines.Text: to access the bolts first remove cap center from wheel by prying with a screwdriver .
using the lug wrench , turn the lug nuts for the front passenger side wheel counterclockwise until you break their resistance .
use your foot or all of your body weight if necessary .
'''++do not++''' remove bolts from the wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: To access the  bolts first remove  cap center from wheel by prying with a screwdriver. Using the lug wrench, turn the lug nuts for the front passenger side wheel counterclockwise until you break their resistance. Use your foot or all of your body weight if necessary. '''++DO NOT++''' remove bolts from the wheel.

Lines.Text: ++'''do not'''++ use the jack to keep the car lifted . place jack stands or cinder blocks underneath the car .
you will need to begin by jacking up the front of your car . if you need help with using a hydraulic jack , see the guide below :
to jack up a car ( or truck )
take the 14 mm lug wrench and loosen all the bolts until they come off of the wheel and remove the wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: ++'''DO NOT'''++ USE THE JACK TO KEEP THE CAR LIFTED. Place jack stands or cinder blocks underneath the car. You will need to begin by jacking up the front of your car. If you need help with  using a hydraulic jack, see the guide below: [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Jack+Up+a+Car+%28or+Truck%29/67013|How to Jack Up a Car (or Truck)] Take the 14mm lug wrench and loosen all the bolts until they come off of the wheel and remove the wheel.

Lines.Text: the sway bar link is located behind the brake shield , connecting the sway bar and suspension .

Steps.Text_raw: The sway bar link is located behind the brake shield, connecting the sway bar and suspension.

Lines.Text: use the penetrating lubricant to spray on the top nut , which attaches the sway bar link to the suspension .
use the penetrating lubricant to spray the bottom nut , which attaches the sway bar link to the sway bar .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the penetrating lubricant to spray on the top nut, which attaches the sway bar link to the suspension. Use the penetrating lubricant to spray the bottom nut, which attaches the sway bar link  to the sway bar.

Lines.Text: use the 14 mm socket wrench to take off the top nut .
if the sway bar link's joint is spinning and the nut does not come off , use the 4 mm allen wrench to hold down the sway bar link . see the second picture for details .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the 14mm socket wrench to take off the top nut. If the sway bar link's joint is spinning and the nut does not come off, use the 4mm Allen wrench to hold down the sway bar link. See the second picture for details.

Lines.Text: repeat step 7 for the bottom nut of the sway bar link .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat Step 7 for the bottom nut of the sway bar link.

Lines.Text: after taking all the nuts off , use the bar from the hydraulic jack to push down the sway bar so that it is easier to take the sway bar link off .

Steps.Text_raw: After taking all the nuts off, use the bar from the hydraulic jack to push down the sway bar so that it is easier to take the sway bar link off.

Lines.Text: to put the new sway bar link in , use the bar from the hydraulic jack to push down the sway bar , and then insert the new sway bar link .

Steps.Text_raw: To put the new sway bar link in, use the bar from the hydraulic jack to push down the sway bar, and then insert the new sway bar link.

Lines.Text: use the 4 mm allen wrench or 14 mm socket wrench to tighten the nut onto the bottom sway bar link .
repeat for the top sway bar link .
the 4 mm allen wrench is not necessary for this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the 4mm Allen wrench or 14mm socket wrench to tighten the nut onto the bottom sway bar link. Repeat for the top sway bar link. The 4mm Allen wrench is not necessary for this step.

Lines.Text: put the tire back on and tighten the lug nuts using the lug wrench .
only tighten tire until there is enough resistance to keep the tire attached to the wheel hub , with the following pattern to ensure proper tire alignment .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the tire back on and tighten the lug nuts using the lug wrench. Only tighten tire until there is enough resistance to keep the tire attached to the wheel hub, with the following pattern to ensure proper tire alignment.

Lines.Text: place the hydraulic jack back under the car and lift it off the cinder blocks or jack stands .
remove the cinder blocks or jack stands and lower the car back to the ground .
further tighten the lug nuts using the torque wrench .
tighten each nut with a torque wrench to a torque of 80 ft/lb . see third picture for pattern to ensure proper tire alignment .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the hydraulic jack back under the car and lift it off the cinder blocks or jack stands. Remove the cinder blocks or jack stands and lower the car back to the ground. Further tighten the lug nuts using the torque wrench. Tighten  each nut with a torque wrench to a torque of 80ft/lb. See third picture for pattern to ensure proper tire alignment.

Subject: Sway Bar Links

Title: Repairing Toyota Sienna Air Filter Vacuum Connector

Toolbox.Name: saw file or dremel rotary tool

Lines.Text: here's what the broken connector looks like . if the broken end is still inside the hose , remove it . insert the end of a a wire clothes hanger through the hole . torque it to get a grip on the tip , and pull and turn until it comes out .

Steps.Text_raw: Here's what the broken connector looks like.  If the broken end is still inside the hose, remove it.  Insert the end of a a wire clothes hanger through the hole.  Torque it to get a grip on the tip, and pull and turn until it comes out.

Lines.Text: to open the housing , you'll need to loosen two bolts on the right side of the housing -- one on the front , and one hiding in the back .
(my wife doesn't think it was necessary to remove the housing , and she may be right . i think it probably made it easier to get the right angles for following steps . )

Steps.Text_raw: To open the housing, you'll need to loosen two bolts on the right side of the housing -- one on the front, and one hiding in the back. (My wife doesn't think it was necessary to remove the housing, and she may be right.  I think it probably made it easier to get the right angles for following steps.)

Lines.Text: use a socket wrench with an extension and 10 mm socket . loosen it with the wrench , then use your fingers to loosen the rest of the way . the bolts are captive , meaning they won't come out all the way .
it takes some finagling to get to the back bolt , and it's cozy , but it's doable .
once both bolts are loosened , grab the right side of the housing , and rotate it firmly but gently up toward the left side , and it should open .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a socket wrench with an extension and 10mm socket.  Loosen it with the wrench, then use your fingers to loosen the rest of the way.  The bolts are captive, meaning they won't come out all the way. It takes some finagling to get to the back bolt, and it's cozy, but it's doable. Once both bolts are loosened, grab the right side of the housing, and rotate it firmly but gently up toward the left side, and it should open.

Lines.Text: cut the remnants of the connector off to make it flush with the housing . this will make it easier to drill in the next step .
you can use a small , flat saw for this . i used my wife's dremel . be careful not to damage other parts of the housing , hoses , etc .
i didn't get a very good photo after the connector was off . you should be able to see the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the remnants of the connector off to make it flush with the housing.  This will make it easier to drill in the next step. You can use a small, flat saw for this.  I used my wife's Dremel.  Be careful not to damage other parts of the housing, hoses, etc. I didn't get a very good photo after the connector was off.  You should be able to see the hole.
Tools_extracted: saw file or dremel rotary tool

Lines.Text: using the hole to center the drill bit , drill out the old connector with a 1 /2 bit . ( if you're an amateur like me , you might try using a smaller bit , say 1 /4 , first for practice , and to make the final hole easier . )
go slowly so you dont damage the housing , and be careful not to cut or damage any other parts . be careful not to go too deep just deep enough that the fitting will be able to go all the way in .
after your hole is done , use a vacuum cleaner to suck out any plastic bits that got into the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the hole to center the drill bit, drill out the old connector with a 1/2" bit.  (If you're an amateur like me, you might try using a smaller bit, say 1/4", first for practice, and to make the final hole easier.) Go slowly so you don’t damage the housing, and be careful not to cut or damage any other parts.  Be careful not to go too deep – just deep enough that the fitting will be able to go all the way in. After your hole is done, use a vacuum cleaner to suck out any plastic bits that got into the hole.

Lines.Text: wrap the fitting with two layers of teflon tape in a clockwise direction ( if youre looking at the threaded end if you go the wrong way , the tape will unravel when youre screwing the fitting in ) .
put the fitting into the hole , and use a 9 /16 wrench to screw it in until its flush with the housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Wrap the fitting with two layers of Teflon tape in a clockwise direction (if you’re looking at the threaded end – if you go the wrong way, the tape will unravel when you’re screwing the fitting in). Put the fitting into the hole, and use a 9/16” wrench to screw it in until it’s flush with the housing.

Lines.Text: if you need to change your air filter , do so now .

close the housing get the tabs on the left slide into their slots first , and then you should be able to rotate the right side down to get it into place . hand-tighten the bolts , then tighten them down with the socket wrench .
slide the hose onto the barb as far as it will go , and voila , your sienna is fixed ! for under 10 !
if ''i'' can fix it , ''anybody'' can .

Steps.Text_raw: If you need to change your air filter, do so now. Close the housing – get the tabs on the left slide into their slots first, and then you should be able to rotate the right side down to get it into place.  Hand-tighten the bolts, then tighten them down with the socket wrench. Slide the hose onto the barb as far as it will go, and voila, your Sienna is fixed!  For under $10! If ''I'' can fix it, ''anybody'' can.

Lines.Text: locate the oil drain plug . the plug is located underneath the front of the truck on the bottom of the engine crank case .
warm up the engine by letting it run or driving it for 10-20 minutes to ensure the oil will flow easily .
be careful not to touch the engine as it will be hot .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil drain plug. The plug is located underneath the front of the truck on the bottom of the engine crank case. Warm up the engine by letting it run or driving it for 10-20 minutes to ensure the oil will flow easily. Be careful not to touch the engine as it will be hot.

Lines.Text: place the drain pan under the drain plug so it will catch the oil as it falls vertically from the engine .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the drain pan under the drain plug so it will catch the oil as it falls vertically from the engine.

Lines.Text: loosen the drain plug by turning the 14 mm socket counterclockwise .
avoid getting oil on the ground by moving the oil pan accordingly .
move your hand away from under the drain plug quickly after loosening it to avoid getting hot oil on your hand .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the drain plug by turning the 14mm socket counterclockwise. Avoid getting oil on the ground by moving the oil pan accordingly. Move your hand away from under the drain plug quickly after loosening it to avoid getting hot oil on your hand.

Lines.Text: pull the hood release latch . the latch is located inside of the car under the steering wheel .
pull the hood release . the release is located under the front center of the hood .
use the hood support rod to keep the hood propped up . the rod is located along the front edge of the engine compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the hood release latch. The latch is  located  inside of the car under the steering wheel. Pull the hood release. The release is located under the front center of the hood. Use the hood support rod to keep the hood propped up. The rod is located along the front edge of the engine compartment.

Lines.Text: locate the oil filter in the engine compartment . the oil filter is on the lower right side of the engine .
remove the filter by turning it counterclockwise with a wrench .
the wrench wraps around the filter and tightens itself as you turn it counterclockwise .
use force if the filter is difficult to remove .
the oil filter may be hot .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil filter in the engine compartment. The oil filter is on the lower right side of the engine. Remove the filter by turning it counterclockwise with a wrench . The wrench wraps around the filter and tightens itself as you turn it counterclockwise. Use force if the filter is difficult to remove. The oil filter may be hot.

Lines.Text: apply a small amount of fresh oil to the edge of the new filter .
use your hand to tighten the new filter until it fits snugly .
as the engine runs , it will cause the filter to tighten itself , so it is unnecessary to use additional force to tighten the filter .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply a small amount of fresh oil to the edge of the new filter. Use your hand to tighten the new filter until it fits snugly. As the engine runs, it will cause the filter to tighten itself, so it is unnecessary to use additional force to tighten the filter.

Lines.Text: set the torque wrench to 32 ft-lbs .
check if all of the oil has drained from the engine by seeing if the oil is still flowing into the drain pan .
wipe any spills on the ground .
replace the drain plug .
use the 14 mm socket torque wrench to tighten the drain plug until the wrench makes a clicking noise .
do not over tighten the drain plug with the torque wrench . too much force could cause the head of the bolt to snap off and become stuck in the engine .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the  torque wrench to 32 ft-lbs. Check if all of the oil has drained from the engine by seeing if the oil is still flowing into the drain pan. Wipe any spills on the ground. Replace the drain plug. Use the 14mm socket torque wrench to tighten the drain plug until the wrench makes a "clicking" noise. Do  not over tighten the drain plug with the torque wrench. Too much force could cause the head of the bolt to snap off and become stuck in the engine.

Lines.Text: locate the oil fill cap in the engine compartment . the cap is located on the lower right side of the engine next to the oil filter .
remove the cap by unscrewing it counterclockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil fill cap in the engine compartment. The cap is located  on the lower right side of the engine next to the oil filter. Remove the cap by unscrewing  it counterclockwise.

Lines.Text: place the funnel into the oil fill tube .
pour 5 quarts of new oil into the funnel .
replace the oil fill cap .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the funnel into the oil fill tube. Pour 5 quarts of new oil into the funnel. Replace the oil fill cap.

Lines.Text: start the truck and let it run for 5 minutes before turning off the engine .
locate the engine dipstick . the dipstick is located on the left side of the engine compartment and is designated by a yellow ring .
remove the dipstick and wipe it clean .
reinsert and remove the dipstick to see if the oil is between the two dots on the dipstick .
the job is finished if the oil is between or slightly above the two dots .
if the oil is below the two dots , add new oil in small increments into the oil fill tube until the dipstick shows it is between the two dots .
do not pour oil into the dipstick tube .

Steps.Text_raw: Start the truck and let it run for 5 minutes before turning off the engine. Locate the engine dipstick. The dipstick is located on the left side of the engine compartment and is designated by a yellow ring. Remove the dipstick and wipe it clean. Reinsert and remove the dipstick to  see if the oil is between the two dots on the dipstick. The job is finished if the oil is between or slightly above the two dots. If the oil is below the two dots,  add new oil in small increments into the oil fill tube until the dipstick shows it is between the two dots. Do not pour oil into the dipstick tube.

Title: How to Replace the Wiper Arm(s) of a 2005 Toyota Corolla

Lines.Text: take the tip of your flathead screwdriver , and wedge it underneath the wiper cap .
firmly pry the wiper cap ++upwards++ until it's completely off .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the tip of your flathead screwdriver, and wedge it underneath the wiper cap. Firmly pry the wiper cap ++upwards++ until it's completely off.

Lines.Text: place the head of your ratchet on the exposed nut .
loosen the nut by turning your ratchet counter clockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the head of your ratchet on the exposed nut. Loosen the nut by turning your ratchet counter clockwise.

Lines.Text: once the nut is loose enough , you may grab it and place it to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the nut is loose enough, you may grab it and place it to the side.

Lines.Text: firmly grip the lower end of the wiper arm .
pull it towards you , so that the wiper arm is extended in the upward position .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grip the lower end of the wiper arm. Pull it towards you, so that the wiper arm is extended in the upward position.

Lines.Text: while holding the lower end of the wiper arm , tug the wiper arm upwards until completely detached .
don't be discouraged if the wiper arm isn't detached right away . you may have to tug upwards a few times to detach it .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the lower end of the wiper arm, tug the wiper arm upwards until completely detached. Don't be discouraged if the wiper arm isn't detached right away. You may have to tug upwards a few times to detach it.

Lines.Text: have your new wiper arm extended in the upward position ( just how your old wiper arm was extended at the end of step 4 ) .
take your wiper arm , and center its hole on the exposed metal threading .

Steps.Text_raw: Have your new wiper arm extended in the upward position (just how your old wiper arm was extended at the end of Step 4). Take your wiper arm, and center its hole on the exposed metal threading.

Lines.Text: once the wiper arm has been placed onto the metal threading , firmly grip the lower end of the wiper arm .
slowly push the wiper arm downwards and away from you , so that it's flat with the windshield .
make sure to do this slowly so that your fingers are not compressed by the wiper arm and the windshield .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the wiper arm has been placed onto the metal threading, firmly grip the lower end of the wiper arm. Slowly push the wiper arm downwards and away from you, so that it's flat with the windshield. Make sure to do this slowly so that your fingers are not compressed by the wiper arm and the windshield.

Lines.Text: place the same nut from earlier onto the exposed threaded metal .
place the head of your ratchet onto the nut .
tighten the nut by turning your ratchet clockwise , until it can no longer be tightened .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the same nut from earlier onto the exposed threaded metal. Place the head of your ratchet onto the nut. Tighten the nut by turning your ratchet clockwise, until it can no longer be tightened.

Lines.Text: firmly press the wiper cap upon the exposed nut .
once the wiper cap is secure , you may repeat steps 1-9 to the other wiper arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly press the wiper cap upon the exposed nut. Once the wiper cap is secure, you may repeat steps 1-9 to the other wiper arm.

Subject: Wiper Arm

Lines.Text: first the truck should be prepared to be worked on .
disconnect the negative battery terminal from the battery in order to be sure that no electrical current is running through the truck .
set the parking break and put the truck in 1 st gear .
be sure to chock the wheels , so that it will not roll while you are underneath .

Steps.Text_raw: First the truck should be prepared to be worked on. Disconnect the negative battery terminal from the battery in order to be sure that no electrical current is running through the truck. Set the parking break and put the truck in 1st gear. Be sure to chock the wheels, so that it will not roll while you are underneath.

Lines.Text: locate the idler arm .
it can be found underneath the vehicle , next to the front passenger tire bolted onto the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the idler arm. It can be found underneath the vehicle, next to the front passenger tire bolted onto the frame.

Lines.Text: the first step is to remove the set nut holding the arm to the relay rod .
begin with cleaning any oil and dirt from the set nut and then spray with the penetrating lubricant .
once the spray has sat for 5 minutes , use needle nose pliers to straighten the cotter pin and pull it out .
during reassembly , never reuse a cotter pin . a new one should be included in a new arm . if a new arm is not purchased then one can be purchased from an auto parts store .
remove the set nut using a 19 mm socket .
when installing the arm this nut should be torqued to 43 ft . -lb .

Steps.Text_raw: The first step is to remove the set nut holding the arm to the relay rod. Begin with cleaning any oil and dirt from the set nut and then spray with the penetrating lubricant. Once the spray has sat for 5 minutes, use needle nose pliers to straighten the cotter pin and pull it out. During reassembly, never reuse a cotter pin. A new one should be included in a new arm. If a new arm is not purchased then one can be purchased from an auto parts store. Remove the set nut using a 19 mm socket. When  installing the arm this nut should be torqued to 43 ft.-lb.

Lines.Text: now that the relay rods are disconnected , the arm can be unbolted from the frame .
spray both the bolts and the nuts with the penetrating lubricant .
on the bolt head use the breaker bar and 17 mm socket ; put the 17 mm box wrench on the nut on the back side of the arm .
the wrench will get stuck on the frame and the breaker bar can then be used to break the rust off the bolt holding it onto the frame .
once the bolt is loose a socket wrench can replace the breaker bar to make the job easier .
the ( 2 ) 4 1 /4 bolts go on either side of the arm . the ( 1 ) 3 1 /2 bolt goes at the top .
all three bolts should be torqued to 70 ft-lb when putting the arm back on .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the relay rods are disconnected, the arm can be unbolted from the frame. Spray both the bolts and the nuts with the penetrating lubricant. On the bolt head use the breaker bar and 17 mm socket; put the 17 mm box wrench on the nut on the back side of the arm. The wrench will get stuck on the frame and the breaker bar can then be used to break the rust off the bolt holding it onto the frame. Once the bolt is loose a socket wrench can replace the breaker bar to make the job easier. The (2) 4 1/4"  bolts go on either side of the arm. The (1) 3 1/2" bolt goes at the top. All three bolts should be torqued to 70 ft-lb when putting the arm back on.

Lines.Text: to separate the arm from the relay rods , a hammer may be used to gently tap up on the idler arm .
do not hit down on the relay rods ; doing so may cause damage and require them to be replaced .
a pitman arm puller can be used if the hammer is not able to knock it loose .
the idler arm can now be removed from the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: To separate the arm from the relay rods, a hammer may be used to gently tap up on the idler arm. Do not hit down on the relay rods; doing so may cause damage and require them to be replaced. A pitman arm puller can be used if the hammer is not able to knock it loose. The idler arm can now be removed from the frame.

Lines.Text: first the idler arm must be removed from the truck . another guide has instructions to take the arm off .

Steps.Text_raw: First the Idler arm must be removed from the truck. Another guide has instructions to [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/1984-1989+Toyota+4Runner+Idler+Arm+Replacement/53763| take the arm off.]

Lines.Text: place the arm in a vise .
spray the cap with penetrating lubricant .
using a screwdriver , tap the idler arm bracket cap off .
if it will not come off easily , then check out the shooting page .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the arm in a vise. Spray the cap with penetrating lubricant. Using a screw driver, tap the idler arm bracket cap off. If it will not come off easily, then check out the [https://www.ifixit.com/Wiki/1984-1989_Toyota_4Runner_Troubleshooting|trouble shooting page.]

Lines.Text: using a 19 mm socket , take the nut off from inside the idler arm bracket .
if the arm rotates in the bracket , then it can be taken out of the vice and placed on the ground .
once on the ground , your foot can be used to stop the arm from rotating and enable you to put torque on the nut .
once the nut is off , the arm can be gently tapped out of the bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a 19 mm socket, take the nut off from inside the idler arm bracket. If the arm rotates in the bracket, then it can be taken out of the vice and placed on the ground. Once on the ground, your foot can be used to stop the arm from rotating and enable you to put torque on the nut. Once the nut is off, the arm can be gently tapped out of the bracket.

Lines.Text: remove the oil seal .
remove the plastic bushings with a flat head .
both bushings and oil seals should be removed and replaced .
fill the bracket with mp grease and then put the arm back into the bracket .
wipe off any grease that squeezes out of the bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the oil seal. Remove the plastic bushings with a flat head. Both bushings and oil seals should be removed and replaced. Fill the bracket with MP grease and then put the arm back into the bracket. Wipe off any grease that squeezes out of the bracket.

Lines.Text: remove cap and squeeze metal brackets revealed underneath to loosen and remove from interior of car .
make a note of where the clips of the lever arm fit into the interior of car for reinstatement of the visor later .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove cap and squeeze metal brackets revealed underneath to loosen and  remove from interior of car. Make a note of where the clips of the lever arm fit into the interior of car for reinstatement of the visor later.

Lines.Text: tear open the seam surrounding the hole that the swing arm inserts into with a seam ripper .
pull the fabric back to show the inner casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Tear open the seam surrounding the hole that the swing arm inserts into with a  seam ripper. Pull the fabric back to show the inner casing.

Lines.Text: reinsert the swing arm back into the visor , make sure the metal prongs on the swing arm line up with the holes on the visor .
the red squares show where the metal prongs fit into the holes of the visor .

Steps.Text_raw: Reinsert the swing arm back into the visor, make sure the metal prongs on the swing arm line up with the holes on the visor. The red squares show where the metal prongs fit into the holes of the visor.

Lines.Text: fold the aluminum plate around the outer casing to reinforce the arm in the casing .
the metal plate will hold both halves of the visor to the lever arm , so make sure it is secured tightly around visor to keep it together .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the aluminum plate around the outer casing to reinforce the arm in the casing. The metal plate will hold both halves of the visor to the lever arm, so make sure it is secured tightly around visor to  keep it together.

Lines.Text: screw a one inch screw through the metal plate and plastic casing using a phillips head screwdriver .
make sure screw goes all the way through to the other side to effectively secure plate to visor .

Steps.Text_raw: Screw a one inch screw through the metal plate and plastic casing using a phillips head screwdriver. Make sure screw goes all the way through to the other side to effectively secure plate to visor.

Lines.Text: adhere the two halves of the torn seam back together over the outer casing and the aluminum plate using upholstery glue .
allow the glue to properly dry before replacing visor back into car .

Steps.Text_raw: Adhere the two halves of the torn seam back together over the outer casing and the aluminum plate​ using upholstery glue. Allow the glue to properly dry before replacing visor back into car.

Lines.Text: realign the metal clips of the swing arm to the hole in the car and snap the visor back into place .
if you go back to step one , the hinges are marked to show where the insert the swing arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Realign the metal clips of the swing arm to the hole in the car and snap the visor back into place. If you go back to step one, the hinges are marked to show where the insert the swing arm.

Lines.Text: begin by applying the parking brake . the parking brake is located below the left side of the driver's console . push it down until it is fully engaged .
locate the 14 mm hex oil drain plug . the drain plug is underneath the truck in the middle of the plate after the skid plate .
place an oil drain pan under the oil drain plug .
be sure to position the drain pan so that it will catch the oil when it is streaming out of the pan .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by applying the parking brake. The parking brake is located  below the left side of the driver's console. Push it down until it is fully engaged. Locate the 14 mm hex oil drain plug. The drain plug is underneath the truck in the middle of the plate after the skid plate. Place an oil drain pan under the oil drain plug. Be sure to position the drain pan so that it will catch the oil when it is streaming out of the pan.

Lines.Text: always wear protective gloves and eyewear when working with motor oil . be careful if your car has been running recently as the engine , transmission , and exhaust may be very hot . keep rags or towels nearby to wipe up any spills .
use a 14 mm box end wrench or socket wrench to loosen the oil drain plug by turning it counter-clockwise until you can turn it by hand .
finish removing the oil drain plug by hand to allow the oil to drain .
watch the draining oil for shiny specks . the shiny specks may be metal flakes and could mean there is a serious problem with your engine internals .

Steps.Text_raw: Always wear protective gloves and eyewear when working with motor oil. Be careful if your car has been running recently as the engine, transmission, and exhaust may be very hot. Keep rags or towels nearby to wipe up any spills. Use a 14 mm box end wrench or socket wrench to loosen the oil drain plug by turning it counter-clockwise until you can turn it by hand. Finish removing the oil drain plug by hand to allow the oil to drain. Watch the draining oil for shiny specks. The shiny specks may be metal flakes and could mean there is a serious problem with your engine internals.

Lines.Text: clean the drain plug and gasket .
remove the gasket from the drain plug and inspect both parts for damage . replace either part if necessary .

if there is no gasket on the drain plug , check the oil pan of the truck to see if it is stuck . if it is , you can use the drain plug or a blade screwdriver to pull it off . be careful to not damage the gasket or oil pan when removing a stuck gasket .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the drain plug and gasket. Remove the gasket from the drain plug and inspect both parts for damage. Replace either part if necessary. If there is no gasket on the drain plug, check the oil pan of the truck to see if it is stuck. If it is, you can use the drain plug or a blade screw driver to pull it off. Be careful to not damage the gasket or oil pan when removing a stuck gasket.

Lines.Text: once the draining oil has slowed to a drip , put the oil drain plug back into its hole and turn it clockwise by hand as far as possible .
continue turning the drain plug clockwise with a 14 mm box end wrench or socket until it is snug .
only tighten the drain plug until it is snug . over-tightening the oil drain plug can strip the threads or crack the oil pan .
wipe off any oil left on the oil pan with a clean rag or towel .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the draining oil has slowed to a drip, put the oil drain plug back into its hole and turn it clockwise by hand as far as possible. Continue turning the drain plug clockwise with a 14 mm box end wrench or socket until it is snug. Only tighten the drain plug until it is snug. Over-tightening the oil drain plug can strip the threads or crack the oil pan. Wipe off any oil left on the oil pan with a clean rag or towel.

Lines.Text: locate the four 12 mm hex bolts holding the skid plate to the chassis .
support the skid plate with one hand and use a 12 mm socket wrench to turn the four bolts counter-clockwise until they come out .
be cautious and alert while removing the skid plate . the skid plate or any debris trapped inside may fall on you .
lower the skid plate from the underside of the truck and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the four 12 mm hex bolts holding the skid plate to the chassis. Support the skid plate with one hand and use a 12 mm socket wrench to turn the four bolts counter-clockwise until they come out. Be cautious and alert while removing the skid plate. The skid plate or any debris trapped inside may fall on you. Lower the skid plate from the underside of the truck and set it aside.

Lines.Text: locate the oil filter . it is on the driver's side of the oil pan and above the steering linkages .
slide the oil drain pan below the oil filter so that it will catch any oil that drips down when the oil filter is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil filter. It is on the driver's side of the oil pan and above the steering linkages. Slide the oil drain pan below the oil filter so that it will catch any oil that drips down when the oil filter is removed.

Lines.Text: turn the oil filter counter-clockwise by hand until it comes off the engine's oil filter threads .
if the filter is too tight to turn by hand , use an oil filter wrench .
lower the oil filter out of the engine bay with the threaded end facing up to reduce the amount of oil spilled .
place the oil filter into the oil drain pan with its open end facing down .
wipe off the engine's oil filter gasket face with a clean rag or towel .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the oil filter counter-clockwise by hand until it comes off the engine's oil filter threads. If the filter is too tight to turn by hand, use an oil filter wrench. Lower the oil filter out of the engine bay with the threaded end facing up to reduce the amount of oil spilled. Place the oil filter into the oil drain pan with its open end facing down. Wipe off the engine's oil filter gasket face with a clean rag or towel.

Lines.Text: pour a small amount of oil into the lid of the oil bottle .
dip a clean , gloved finger into the lid with oil .
use your wetted finger to spread a thin layer of oil onto the gasket of the new oil filter .
fill the oil filter 1 /3 of the way full with new oil . this will ensure the truck has oil as soon as the truck is started .

Steps.Text_raw: Pour a small amount of oil into the lid of the oil bottle. Dip a clean, gloved finger into the lid with oil. Use your wetted finger to spread a thin layer of oil onto the gasket of the new oil filter. Fill the oil filter 1/3 of the way full with new oil. This will ensure the truck has oil as soon as the truck is started.

Lines.Text: place the threaded end of the oil filter onto the engine's oil filter threads , being careful to not get dirt or debris on the filter's gasket .
turn the filter clockwise by hand until it is snug .
if the filter is difficult to turn at the beginning of its threads , stop ! you may be cross threading the oil filter . re-align the oil filter and try again .
do not over-tighten your oil filter by using a wrench . doing so may cause the oil filter seal to leak and will make removing the oil filter very difficult in the future .
remove the oil drain pan from underneath the truck .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the threaded end of the oil filter onto the engine's oil filter threads, being careful to not get dirt or debris on the filter's gasket. Turn the filter clockwise by hand until it is snug. If the filter is difficult to turn at the beginning of its threads, stop! You may be cross threading the oil filter. Re-align the oil filter and try again. Do not over-tighten your oil filter by using a wrench. Doing so may cause the oil filter seal to leak and will make removing the oil filter very difficult in the future. Remove the oil drain pan from underneath the truck.

Lines.Text: put the skid plate back into place and support it with one hand . use your other hand to reinsert the 12 mm bolts , turning them clockwise about two turns .
make sure the two tabs on the skid plate are inserted into their respective holes as indicated in picture 2.
use the 12 mm socket wrench to finish turning the bolts clockwise until they are snug .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the skid plate back into place and support it with one hand. Use your other hand to reinsert the 12 mm bolts, turning them clockwise about two turns. Make sure the two tabs on the skid plate are inserted into their respective holes as indicated in picture 2. Use the 12 mm socket wrench to finish turning the bolts clockwise until they are snug.

Lines.Text: locate the hood release lever . it is below the left side of the driver's console . pull it until you hear the hood click .
go to the front of the truck and locate the hood release latch . it will be under the hood and slightly towards the driver's side of the truck .
use one hand to lift up on the latch and your other hand to lift the hood open .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the hood release lever. It is below the left side of the driver's console. Pull it until you hear the hood click. Go to the front of the truck and locate the hood release latch. It will be under the hood and slightly towards the driver's side of the truck. Use one hand to lift up on the latch and your other hand to lift the hood open.

Lines.Text: locate the oil filler cap on the driver's side valve cover .
turn the cap counter-clockwise , then pull it off the valve cover .
insert funnel .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil filler cap on the driver's side valve cover. Turn the cap counter-clockwise, then pull it off the valve cover. Insert funnel.

Lines.Text: pour 6.5 quarts of 5 w-30 automobile oil into the engine . use one hand to stabilize the funnel to help prevent spills .
consult your owner's manual if you think your operating conditions call for a different oil viscosity .
remove the funnel and put the oil filler cap back over the oil filler hole . turn the cap clockwise until it is snug and you hear a click .

Steps.Text_raw: Pour 6.5 quarts of 5W-30 automobile oil into the engine. Use one hand to stabilize the funnel to help prevent spills. Consult your owner's manual if you think your operating conditions call for a different oil viscosity. Remove the funnel and put the oil filler cap back over the oil filler hole. Turn the cap clockwise until it is snug and you hear a click.

Lines.Text: locate the yellow oil dipstick next to the passenger's side valve cover .
do not confuse the oil dipstick for the transmission fluid dipstick , which has an orange handle and is in the same general area .
pull out the oil dipstick , wipe it off , place it all the way back into its hole , and remove it again .
check the oil level on the end of the dipstick . it should be within the two holes , or slightly above the top most hole .

this is not your actual oil level , but a pre-check to make sure the engine will not run dry when you first start it . the oil level will drop slightly after the first run when oil completely fills the new oil filter .
add oil if the oil level is below the bottom most hole of the dipstick . place the oil dipstick all the way back in its hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the yellow oil dipstick next to the passenger's side valve cover. Do not confuse the oil dipstick for the transmission fluid dipstick, which has an orange handle and is in the same general area. Pull out the oil dipstick, wipe it off, place it all the way back into its hole, and remove it again. Check the oil level on the end of the dipstick. It should be within the two holes, or slightly above the top most hole. This is not your actual oil level, but a pre-check to make sure the engine will not run dry when you first start it. The oil level will drop slightly after the first run when oil completely fills the new oil filter. Add oil if the oil level is below the bottom most hole  of the dipstick. Place the oil dipstick all the way back in its hole.

Lines.Text: gently lower the hood until it clicks into the secondary latch .
press firmly on the edge of the hood until you hear the primary latch engage .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lower the hood until it clicks into the secondary latch. Press firmly on the edge of the hood until you hear the primary latch engage.

Lines.Text: start the truck and look for leaks underneath it . if there are leaks , shut the truck off and determine if the drain plug or filter need to be tightened .

after running the engine for a few minutes , let it cool down for at least 15 minutes re-check the oil level . if the oil level is more than a 1 /2 above the top hole of the dipstick you will need to drain oil . if the oil level is below the bottom hole of the dipstick you will need to add oil .
allow 12-24 hours for all the oil to drain out of your old oil filter .

take your old oil and filter to a recycling facility . most auto parts stores and repair shops accept these at no charge . some cities and/or counties have a service where they will collect used oil and filters from your home . for more information , see the american petroleum institute's web page on used motor oil collection and recycling .

Steps.Text_raw: Start the truck and look for leaks underneath it. If there are leaks, shut the truck off and determine if the drain plug or filter need to be tightened. After running the engine for a few minutes, let it cool down for at least 15 minutes re-check the oil level. If the oil level is more than a 1/2" above the top hole of the dipstick you will need to drain oil. If the oil level is below the bottom hole of the dipstick you will need to add oil. Allow 12-24 hours for all the oil to drain out of your old oil filter. Take your old oil and filter to a recycling facility. Most auto parts stores and repair shops accept these at no charge. Some cities and/or counties have a service where they will collect used oil and filters from your home. For more information, see the American Petroleum Institute's web page on used motor oil collection and recycling.
